title: 105_s770
content: The Act may be cited as the "Domestic Oil and Gas Preservation Act" and includes an election to expense geological and geophysical expenditures. The "Domestic Oil and Gas Preservation Act" allows taxpayers to deduct geological and geophysical expenses for oil and gas exploration in the United States as current expenses, effective for expenses incurred after the enactment of the Act. The "Domestic Oil and Gas Preservation Act" allows taxpayers to deduct geological and geophysical expenses for oil and gas exploration in the United States as current expenses. Expenses paid or incurred after the enactment of the Act can be amortized over a 36-month period, while expenses paid or incurred before the enactment can also be amortized if the taxpayer elects to do so. Elimination of net income limitation on percentage depletion for oil and gas. The net income limitation for percentage depletion in oil and gas wells is eliminated, with the allowance not exceeding 50 percent of taxable income from the property. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1997. (A) Deduction disallowed under section 613A of the Internal Revenue Code for taxable years ending on or before December 31, 1997, will be allowed as a deduction for the first taxable year after December 31, 1997. Certain adjustments from the previous code will apply to these deductions. SEC. 4. ELECTION TO EXPENSE DELAY RENTAL PAYMENTS. The amendment allows taxpayers to deduct delay rental payments for domestic oil and gas wells as expenses in the year they are paid or incurred, rather than capitalizing them. The amendment allows taxpayers to deduct delay rental payments for domestic oil and gas wells as expenses in the year they are paid or incurred, rather than capitalizing them. A conforming amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 specifies the effective date for these changes and provides a transition rule for payments made before the enactment of the Act. The unamortized portion of any payment is the amount remaining unamortized as of the first day of the 36-month period. SEC. 5 extends the spudding rule from the 90th day to the 180th day for oil or gas wells. SEC. 6 includes hydro injection as a tertiary recovery method for enhanced oil recovery projects starting after December 31, 1997.
